chapter.title: Module
chapter.para: The enhances the level of communication between the different actors of international trade operations.

note.para: Collaboration Suite is available for the customers' users and middle-office, for both cash and trade modules. For Counterparties, it is applicable only for trade.

section.title: Overview
section.para: As a client user you can:

listitem.para: Create a list of tasks for any event of any trade product (Import Letter of Credit, Banker's Guarantee, etc.).
Assign tasks to users in your company, and follow up each these tasks through reports and a system of automatic alerts.
Assign tasks to the company's bank and communicate freely with the bank during the preparation phase of a transaction.
Assign tasks to a counterparty and communicate freely with the counterparty during the preparation phase of a transaction.

section.para: There are 3 different types of tasks:

listitem.para: Private task - created, maintained and visible only by the user who created it.
Public task - created by an initial user, it is visible to all users in the same company and entity as the one attached to the transaction to which the task is associated.
Assigned task - created by an initial user and assigned to either:
another user in the same company. The task is only visible to these two users, and only these users can update its status,
an external party, that is, the bank or a counterparty. The task is visible to all users in the same entity as the initial user, and by all users in the external company.

section.para: Typically, a task is a question asked by the current user, who needs information from a colleague, a counterparty or the bank in order to complete the transaction.
Any user with access to a task can add a comment to it. These comments are visible to the users according to the same rules as the visibility of a task.
In the same way, you can define alerts:

listitem.para: When you create a task, you indicate if you want to be notified by e-mail of events occurring on this task,
When you assign a task, you indicate if you want the assignee to be notified by e-mail.

section.para: When the Collaboration Suite is enabled, a task list, initially empty, is created for each transaction managed in such as, for instance, the initiation of an Import Letter of Credit or the amendment of a Banker's Guarantee, etc. This task list is maintained by the users in your company until the transaction is submitted to the bank. From this moment, the list of tasks is frozen but the company's users can still access the history of the transaction's tasks and comments.

section.title: Task Windows
section.para: Your client user interface has three different windows that display lists of tasks. We describe here the different ways they are used. Later sections in this chapter describe their layout in detail.

section.title: Collaboration Window (Tasks)
section.para:
When you use any function that initiates a transaction, the form that opens has attached to it a free-floating window entitled Tasks. This is known as the Collaboration Window. It is initially displayed minimized when the form opens. Click the maximize button
in its title bar to see it fully.

You use this window to create tasks for the transaction you are creating or editing. To do so, you click Add a task, fill in a small sub-form, and click OK. Only when a record for the transaction exists is there anything for the task to attach to, so even though you have clicked OK, the task is not saved until you have saved the transaction by clicking Save or Submit on the main form. However, once the record exists, any task you add, any edits you make to a task, or comments that you add to it, are saved as soon as you click OK.

For example, say you create a task in LC Initiation > From Scratch, then save the form. If you later re-open the form using LC Initation > Retrieve Draft, you will see the task in the list in the Collaboration Window. So will any other user in your company who re-opens the form, provided the task is in the main part of the list (headed Tasks) and not in the part containing tasks you intend for yourself (headed My Tasks).

To reply to a task, you add a comment to it. To do this, click Comments by its entry to display all its existing comments, and then click Post Comment. Users other than the creator cannot edit the task, but can add comments. These comments typically form a conversation between the creator of a task and the person who carries it out.

Each task has a check box on the left-hand side. This is called the completion check box. The user who carries out the task should click to put a check mark here. Once this is done, the creator can no longer edit the task, but people can still add comments to it.

section.title: Ongoing Tasks
section.para: This list is part of your home page. It lists all tasks that are available for you yourself to do. That is, tasks you've created for yourself to do, tasks that another user in your company has assigned to you, and tasks that a user in your company has marked Public, so that any user in the company can pick the task up and do it.

One column shows the System Id of the transaction that the task is attached to. Clicking this opens the form (like LC Initiation > Retrieve Draft), including the Collaboration Window, for further editing of the transaction.
When another user updates a task, the change appears on your Ongoing Tasks list as soon as you refresh your screen (typically done using F5).
The Ongoing Tasks list does not show comments. Once a task has been marked completed it disappears from this list.

section.title: Tasks Monitoring
section.para: You access this list by clicking Reports on your main menu to display the Message Center menu, and then clicking Tasks Monitoring. This is the fullest list, in that it can show all tasks, both open and completed, and all comments. It has search criteria fields, so you can select which items to show. Note that the Date range fields both default to today's date, so when you first display the list you see only the entries created today.

section.title: Collaboration Window
section.para: This section describes the Collaboration Window in detail.

In the input form for every event of every product and in the transaction's details screen in the history, there is a window for managing the tasks associated with the current transaction. Here you can:

listitem.para: define a new task,
update the completion status of a task,
add a new comment to a task.

section.title: Tasks Monitoring
section.para: You access the Tasks Monitoring list from your Message Center menu (click Reports on your main menu to open this). It displays a full list of tasks (depending on search criteria).
When you select this option, you are presented with a list of tasks and comments.

You can select which entries are shown, by entering search criteria in the Task Type, Post Date (From and To), System Id, Task Status, and/or Item Type fields. Initially all these fields are blank except that the date fields are set to today's date, so you see all tasks and comments created today.
You can leave the From and/or To fields blank.
You can use wildcards in the System Id field. For example, *5885 will match all system IDs that end in 5885. The comparison is not case sensitive.
If you include comments in the display, only comments attached to tasks of the type and status selected are included.
There is also a download button that allows the results to be saved as a file on the executing PC. Click this button and select the required option from the list shown. The options are:

listitem.para: CSV downloads the list to the PC as Comma-Separated Values file.
Spreadsheet downloads the list to the PC as a Microsoft Excel compatible file.

section.para: Use the CSV or SpreadSheet option to export the list as a report allowing it to be customized further for various office productivity tools. When the browser displays the File Download prompt, save the file (default name is pendingIP.xxx) or directly open it to launch Excel if it is available on the workstation.

section.title: Counterparty Access
section.para: Administrators at your company maintain a list of companies that your company deals with. For example, when creating an Import LC request, you fill in the beneficiary field by selecting a company from this list. These companies are called counterparties.

When the Collaboration Suite is enabled, this feature is enhanced. When an administrator adds a counterparty to the list, the counterparty can be added to the system as a client, with limited access to facilities. This enables the counterparty's staff to view task lists in order to see tasks assigned to their company.
